clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Clinical Trial of Computer-based Motivational Intervention - 1
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Clinical Trial of Computer-based Motivational Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: Pilot trial of computer-based motivational intervention. Hypothesis: The brief computer-delivered intervention would result in higher motivation to change at follow-up.

detailed_description.textblock: Participants were randomized into brief intervention vs. assessment-only conditions, with follow-up to measure overall motivation to change.

primary_outcome.description: An eight-item measure tapping motivation to change, self-efficacy, and change intention was assessed using visual analog scales. The average of the eight items was calculated resulting in a score ranging from 1 to 100. The measure was asked at baseline (reported in baseline data) and the one month follow-up. Scores here represent average level of motivation for change at the time of follow-up. Higher scores represent higher levels of motivation to change, self-efficacy and intention to change.

arm_group.description: A 20-minute interaction with software designed to partially replicate the experience of a brief motivational intervention with a therapist or health care professional. Included decisional balance, normed feedback, and optional goal-setting.
Participants in this arm only completed assessment section, same as intervention group, but then was done.

intervention.description: 20-minute interaction with voice-enabled software that could provide reflections, images, text, etc.

criteria.textblock:
Woman in immediate post-partum period
Inclusion Criteria:
Self-report of drug use prior to pregnancy
Exclusion Criteria:
Frank psychosis or other cognitive impairment; inability to communicate in English; fatigue; recent receipt of narcotic pain medication; grieving over medically compromised infant

results_reference.citation: Ondersma SJ, Chase SK, Svikis DS, Schuster CR. Computer-based brief motivational intervention for perinatal drug use. J Subst Abuse Treat. 2005 Jun;28(4):305-12.

measure.title: Baseline motivation
measure.description: Visual analog scale questions were used to assess baseline motivation, self-efficacy, problem recognition, and change likelihood. The average of the items were calculated for baseline measurement resulting in a score ranging from 1 to 100. Higher scores represent increase motivation for change, self-efficacy, problem recognition and increased likelihood of making a change.

outcome.title: Motivation to Change Substance Use
outcome.description: An eight-item measure tapping motivation to change, self-efficacy, and change intention was assessed using visual analog scales. The average of the eight items was calculated resulting in a score ranging from 1 to 100. The measure was asked at baseline (reported in baseline data) and the one month follow-up. Scores here represent average level of motivation for change at the time of follow-up. Higher scores represent higher levels of motivation to change, self-efficacy and intention to change.
outcome.population: A total of 30 participants were included in this pilot trial, based primarily on convenience and timeframe. The primary goal was effect-size estimation, so power was not a primary concern. Last Observation Carried Forward(LOCF) was utilized for 8 participants lost to follow-up.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Small sample size in the pilot clinical trial. Because of this lack of power, a statistically significant difference between groups was not demonstrated, and the 95% Confidence Interval (CI) for the effect size estimate included zero.
